sect1.title: 149 Cestodes
sect1.para: MIGUEL M. CABADA, JUAN JIMENEZ, AND HECTOR H. GARCIA

Adult cestode tapeworms have a flattened body composed of the scolex, bearing the fixation organs such as suckers, hooks, and bothria; the neck, where the cellular reproduction occurs; and the strobila, formed by numerous segments called proglottids. Proglottids generate in the neck region and mature as they progress distally. The more distal proglottids are gravid and almost completely occupied by a uterus full of eggs. These eggs are passed in the stool of the carrier, either inside intact proglottids or free after the proglottids disintegrate. In some species, motile proglottids can actively migrate out of the anus. Adult tapeworms are hermaphroditic, and each proglottid contains male and female reproductive organs.

Tapeworms live in the lumen of the small intestine, attached to the mucosa by the scolex. They absorb nutrients from the host’s intestine both at the scolex and the strobila by using a specialized tegument (Fig. 1).

There are four common tapeworms that inhabit the human intestine:Dibothriocephalus/Adenocephalus spp., Taenia saginata, Taenia solium, and Hymenolepis nana. They differ widely in size, with Dibothriocephalus latus measuring up to 12 meters and H. nana measuring up to 3 cm. Other important differences include intermediate host range and transmission forms (Table 1). Dipylidium caninum and Hymenolepis diminuta are uncommon tapeworms that can also inhabit the human gut; these parasites are reviewed in chapter 151 of this Manual. In addition, a number of cestode larvae can produce human disease after infective tapeworm eggs are ingested, mainly cysticercosis (T. solium), cystic echinococcosis (Echinococcus granulosus), and alveolar echinococcosis (Echinococcus multilocularis). Uncommon larval cestode infections include coenurosis (Taenia multiceps), sparganosis (Spirometra mansonoides), and cysticercosis (Taenia crassiceps). Tapeworms, and especially tapeworm larval infections, represent an important cause of morbidity and mortality in underdeveloped and industrialized countries, particularly in rural areas and among immigrants from areas of endemicity.

sect2.title: DIBOTHRIOCEPHALUS/DIPHYLLOBOTHRIUM/ADENOCEPHALUS
sect2.para: The fish tapeworm,Dibiothriocephalus latus (formerly Diphyllobothrium latum), is the largest intestinal parasite of humans. Although it can also infect fish-eating mammals such as canids and felids (reservoir hosts), humans are considered the most common hosts (1). Dibothriocephalus nihonkaiense (formerly Diphyllobothrium nihonkaiensi), Adenocephalus pacificus (formerly Diphyllobothrium pacificum), and Diphyllobothrium stemmacephalum are three other representative species of the family Diphyllobothriidae with regional importance.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: D. latus is included in the phylum Platyhelminthes, subphylum Neodermata, class Cestoidea, subclass Eucestoda, order Diphyllobothriidea, family Diphyllobothriidae, and genus Dibothriocephalus.

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: Adult Tapeworm

The adult parasite can measure up to 15 m in length and can live over 20 years in the small intestine. It is ivory in color and has a scolex provided with bothria, which are two longitudinal suction sulci in the dorsal and ventral aspects (2, 3). Dibothriocephalus proglottids are much wider than they are long (ca. 8 by 4 mm) and have a characteristic genital pore in the center of the proglottid rather than in the edges as in all other tapeworms of humans. The coiled uterus in the center of the gravid proglottids looks yellow-brown in freshly passed specimens. The uterine pore is in the center of the proglottid near the genital pore.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: D. latus eggs are oval and are passed unembryonated. The eggs have an operculum and a knob in the obopercular pole, resembling trematode eggs, but are smaller (58 to 75 μm long by 44 to 50 μm wide). The egg output is very high, and the expulsion of strobila fragments or proglottid chains is common.

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Scoleces (top panels), gravid proglottids (middle panels), and eggs (lower panels) of, from left to right, H. nana, T. saginata, T. solium, and Adenocephalus pacificus. Note the coiled, central uterus in A. pacificus, the absence of hooks in the scolex of T. saginata, and the similar appearances of the eggs of T. saginata and T. solium. The morphological characteristics shown for A. pacificus are similar to those of D. latus.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: Eggs embryonate in fresh water for several weeks and release ciliated embryos with six hooks, known as coracidia. These are ingested by freshwater copepods of the genusCyclops. In the copepod, a solid-bodied larva (the procercoid) develops as a second larval stage and becomes infective to freshwater fish, the second intermediate host. In fish, the procercoid migrates to the flesh and develops into the third larval stage, the plerocercoid or sparganum, which is the infective stage for human and animal (canids or felids) hosts.

sect2.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect2.para: The geographic distribution ofD. latus includes lake areas in Scandinavia, other areas of northern Europe, the former Soviet Union, Finland, northern Japan, and North America, principally the upper Midwest, Alaska, and Canada, and the southwestern coast of South America. Several other species (Adenocephalus pacificus, Dibiothriocephalus nihonkaiensis, and Dibothriocephalus dendriticus [formerly Diphyllobothrium dendriticum]) infect humans but less frequently (3, 4). A. pacificum, identified by Nybellin in 1931, is a parasite of seawater found along the western coast of South America, specifically in Peru and Chile. A. pacificum is much smaller than D. latus, measuring 50 to 400 cm long (5).

table.title: TABLE 1 Some characteristics of main cestodes infecting humans

sect2.para: The most common sources of human infection are raw, smoked, or pickled fish such as pike, burbot, perch, ruff, turbot, and Pacific salmon (3). The prevalence of infection increases with age, being the highest in adults (6). Infection with Diphyllobothriidae is preventable by cooking fish thoroughly or by freezing fish (at least −10°C for 24 h).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance (Description of Clinical Presentation)
sect1.para: Infected individuals may notice passing portions of the strobila in their stool. The infection otherwise produces no clinical symptoms in most people. Large-size parasites and infection with multiple parasites may be associated with mechanical bowel obstruction, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. In northern European countries and Chile, pernicious anemia resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency caused by tapeworm uptake of the vitamin has been reported. This condition is rare outside Scandinavian countries, and some authors postulate a genetic predisposition.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: Eggs in stool are well preserved when mixed with 5 to 10% formalin solutions. Ethanol and some commercial matrixes preserve DNA for transport and storage. Electron microscopy may require cacodylate buffer or other glutaraldehyde media. Adult tapeworm specimens are better evaluated if they are relaxed for better visualization of the internal structures by warming in saline at 55°C for a short period (5 min), then placed between two glass slides and stored in a fixative solution. Fixatives could be 10% formalin, acetic acid-formaldehyde-alcohol, or sodium acetate-acetic acid-formaldehyde. Fixed pieces can be stained by injecting Semichon’s carmine or India ink. The proglottids can also be sectioned and stained using hematoxylin and eosin; however, morphological characteristics can be more easily seen in mounted whole proglottids.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Eggs can be easily seen by microscopic examination of stools. Flotation or sedimentation techniques increase the sensitivity of microscopy. Flotation techniques use solutions with specific gravities to make eggs of certain weight go to the surface, which increases the sensitivity of microscopy but decreases the number of species that can be detected. Most laboratories routinely use the sedimentation concentration method, which uses generic solutions and the weight of the eggs to concentrate them in the bottom of the test tube. Low-magnification microscopy should easily permit identification of the characteristic scolex or proglottids when available (Fig. 1). Neither culture nor antigen detection is used for the detection and identification of D. latus.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques
sect2.para: The phylogenetic analysis of theDiphyllobothriidae family has been used to reclassify the most common human parasites (7). However, nucleic acid detection methods are not routinely used in clinical practice to identify tapeworm species (8).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Serologic tests are not available.

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Both praziquantel and niclosamide are effective drugs. At recommended doses, both are associated with only mild gastrointestinal side effects.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Both stool microscopy and parasite identification are highly specific. Eggs or tapeworm sections should be reported asDibothriocephalus sp. eggs or sections (except in South America, where D. latus or A. pacificus may be found).

sect2.title: TAENIA SAGINATA
sect2.para: T. saginata, the beef tapeworm, is endemic to most of the world. Humans are the only definitive host for this tapeworm, and infection carries minimal health risks. Distinguishing T. saginata from T. solium, another tapeworm using humans as definitive host, has important clinical and epidemiologic implications, as the latter can cause neurocysticercosis.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: T. saginata is included in the phylum Platyhelminthes, subphylum Neodermata, class Cestoidea, subclass Eucestoda, order Cyclophyllidea, family Taeniidae, and genus Taenia.

sect2.title: Adult Tapeworm
sect2.para: The adultT. saginata can reach 4 to 8 m in length and has a scolex with four suckers and no hooks. Gravid proglottids are longer than they are wide (18 to 20 mm by 5 to 7 mm). Proglottids have a genital pore at the mid-lateral margin. Mature proglottids have an ovary with only two lobes and >15 primary uterine branches. Gravid proglottids are highly muscular and active, break off from the strobila, and actively migrate out of the anus, which is characteristic of this species.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs fromT. saginata are spherical, measure 30 to 40 μm in diameter, and have a thick, yellow-brown, radiated shell (embryophore) that gets thicker as the eggs mature. T. saginata and T. solium eggs are indistinguishable by microscopy. Eggs are frequently surrounded by a thin layer of vitellum (Fig. 1) and contain a six-hook embryo called the oncosphere.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: The cysticercus is the larval form ofT. saginata that infects cattle. This is a scolex invaginated into a fluid-filled bladder. Cysticerci are 4 to 6 mm long by 7 to 10 mm wide and have a pearl-like appearance in tissues.

sect1.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect1.para: T. saginata is distributed worldwide, but it is especially prevalent in some parts of Africa, Central and South America, eastern and western Asia, and some countries in Europe. Cattle are the intermediate host and are infected after ingesting eggs in contaminated pasturelands. Cattle carry the infective cysticerci in their tissues. Human are infected after the ingestion of cysticerci in raw or inadequately cooked beef. After ingestion, the scolex in the cysticercus evaginates and attaches to the intestinal mucosa. It takes approximately 2 to 3 months for the infection to become patent in the human host.

In Southeast Asia,T. saginata asiatica (Taenia asiatica or Taiwan taenia) is morphologically similar to T. saginata, but the cysticercus stage occurs in the liver of pigs and, less frequently, in cattle. The adult tapeworm infects the humans and is morphologically similar to T. saginata (9, 10).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance (Description of Clinical Presentation)
sect1.para: Patients withT. saginata may be asymptomatic, but notice passing proglottids or find them in their underwear. The infection can cause abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and occasionally intestinal obstruction in patients with a high burden of parasites.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: See instructions in “Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens” forDibothriocephalus.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Taenia spp. eggs can be found in feces. Sedimentation techniques are more sensitive than Kato-Katz for the detection of Taenia eggs in stool. Taenia spp. eggs are morphologically identical, and identification to the species level is not possible by microscopy. In contrast, the evaluation of gravid proglottids that have been passed in feces or have actively migrated out of the anus allows differentiation between T. saginata and other species, except for Taenia asiatica, which has very similar morphologic characteristics. Injection of proglottids with India ink or staining with carmine or hematoxylin stains help with the evaluation of the uterus morphology. T. saginata proglottids have 15 to 20 primary lateral branches on each side of the central uterine stem (Fig. 1).
Stool antigen (coproantigen) may be detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), but this assay is used in epidemiologic research settings and is seldom available for clinical use.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques
sect2.para: Species-specific PCR techniques have been described to detect parasite DNA and differentiateT. saginata from T. solium. These assays can detect Taenia DNA from parasite tissue and stool samples (11–15).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Serum antigen detection ELISA forT. saginata cysticercosis in cattle has been developed using monoclonal antibodies. Although these assays can detect parasite burdens of ≤50 cysts per animal, they are not routinely applied in animal husbandry (16–18).

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Both praziquantel and niclosamide are effective drugs. At recommended doses, both are associated with only mild gastrointestinal side effects. In regions whereT. solium is endemic, praziquantel can affect the viability of latent cysticerci in the brain and can cause severe headaches or seizures. Niclosamide is not absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract and has no effect on tissue cysticerci (19).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Eggs detected in the stool should be reported as “Taenia sp.” because species identification is not possible by microscopy observation. The finding of Taenia sp. eggs should be communicated to the attending physician to ensure prompt treatment. The presence of the scolex in parasite segments expelled spontaneously or after treatment allows the identification to the species level and should be reported, because retention of scolex increases the chances of treatment failure.

sect2.title: TAENIA SOLIUM
sect2.para: T. solium, the pork tapeworm, has an extensive geographic distribution and a large impact on human health due to its association with seizure disorders. T. solium neurocysticercosis is the most common cause of acquired epilepsy in developing countries (20).

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: T. solium is included in the phylum Platyhelminthes, subphylum Neodermata, class Cestoidea, subclass Eucestoda, order Cyclophyllidea, family Taeniidae, and genus Taenia.

sect2.title: Adult Tapeworm
sect2.para: The adultT. solium tapeworm measures 2 to 4 m and has a scolex provided with four suckers and a rostellum with two rows of hooks. Gravid proglottids have similar length and width (approximately 1 cm). Proglottids have a genital pore at the mid-lateral margin. T. solium mature proglottids have an ovary with two main lobes and one accessory lobe, which is absent in T. saginata proglottids, and do not have the vaginal sphincter muscle that is present in T. saginata proglottids. Gravid proglottids have fewer than 12 lateral branches on the central uterine stem (Fig. 1). Since the eggs of T. solium are infective to humans and can cause cysticercosis, extreme caution in the handling of proglottids or egg-containing stool is recommended.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: Eggs fromT. solium and T. saginata are indistinguishable morphologically. They are spherical, measure 30 to 40 μm in diameter, and have a characteristic thick, yellow-brown, radiate shell (embryophore) that gets thicker as the eggs mature. Eggs are frequently surrounded by a thin layer of vitellum (Fig. 1). A six-hook embryo, the oncosphere, is found inside the egg.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: The fluid-filled bladder (cysticercus) larvae are bigger than those ofT. saginata, measuring approximately 8 to 10 mm in diameter. They lodge in the pig’s tissues, mostly in muscle and brain.

sect1.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect1.para: T. solium taeniasis and cysticercosis are highly endemic to parts of the developing world where pigs are raised in family farms as a food source, including Latin America, most Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, and parts of Oceania. The infection is also increasingly diagnosed in industrialized countries due to immigration of tapeworm carriers from areas of endemicity (10, 20).

Humans are the only definitive host ofT. solium. Ingestion of pork containing T. solium cysticerci causes human taeniasis. Ingestion of T. solium eggs causes cysticercosis in pigs (the usual intermediate host) and humans. Pigs acquire cysticercosis by eating human stool containing infective eggs in places with deficient sanitation. Humans are infected by fecal-oral transmission from tapeworm carriers, commonly in households or another close-contact environment. Interruption of T. solium transmission is feasible using human deworming with niclosamide, pig treatment with oxfendazole, and pig vaccination (21).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance (Description of Clinical Presentation)
sect1.para: HumanT. solium taeniasis is acquired by ingestion of infective cysticerci in inadequately cooked pork or pork products. Taeniasis is mostly asymptomatic, and the majority of patients do not notice passing proglottids in the stool. The clinical significance of T. solium infections is associated with the risk of neurocysticercosis (see below), which is high for tapeworm carriers and their close contacts (20).

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: See instructions in “Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens” forDibothriocephalus. Handling of T. solium proglottids or stool potentially containing eggs should be done in appropriate biosafety conditions (biosafety level 2 or higher) to avoid cysticercosis.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Taenia eggs are passed in the stool and can be detected by microscopy. Egg concentration techniques such as sedimentation and the Kato-Katz test increase the sensitivity for egg detection but cannot identify the Taenia species. The evaluation of gravid proglottids or the parasite’s scolex passed in feces allows the identification of the species. The morphology of the uterus can be demonstrated after injection with India ink or staining with carmine or hematoxylin stains. In T. solium there are fewer than 12 primary branches on each side of the central uterine stem (Fig. 1).

Coproantigen ELISA is much more sensitive than microscopy and should be the test of choice to diagnose human taeniasis. Highly sensitive tests are especially important forT. solium because early diagnosis and treatment may prevent cysticercosis transmission. Coproantigen ELISA may also aid in the evaluation of treatment response (22).

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques
sect2.para: Species-specific PCR techniques that differentiateT. saginata from T. solium have been described but are not commercially available. Most of these assays are performed on parasite tissue, but some are able to detect T. solium DNA in stool (11–14). PCR tests to detect T. solium cell-free DNA in urine demonstrated a correlation with subarachnoid and parenchymal neurocysticercosis and may have potential as a noninvasive test to evaluate treatment response (23). Unbiased next-generation sequencing can detect T. solium DNA in cerebrospinal fluid, but its usefulness in clinical settings is to be determined (24).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Stage-specific serologic assays to detect adult tapeworm antibodies have demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity but are not available for clinical use. Most serologic tests are aimed at diagnosing neurocysticercosis. Antibody detection by enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot is 98% sensitive in cases with more than one viable cyst, with a specificity of 100% (25). T. solium antigen can be detected in serum or cerebrospinal fluid of humans with cysticercosis by using the T. saginata ELISA, due to cross-reactivity between antigens from these species. T. solium antigen detection is a helpful tool to monitor the clinical response of patients with severe, subarachnoid neurocysticercosis (26).

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Both praziquantel and niclosamide are effective drugs againstT. solium taeniasis. However, in regions of endemicity and among T. solium-infected patients, niclosamide should be the preferred drug. Praziquantel may have an effect on viable brain cisticerci, leading to severe headaches or seizures. Niclosamide cannot cause the same complication, as it is not absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract (19).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Eggs detected by microscopy should be reported as “Taenia sp.” because species identification is not possible with this technique. Health care providers should be notified about the observation of Taenia sp. eggs in the stool to prompt treatment and minimize the risk of cysticercosis in the patient and the patient’s contacts. The identification of a scolex in the parasite segments expelled spontaneously or after treatment allows the identification of the Taenia species. Retention of the scolex after treatment should also be reported because it is associated with increased treatment failure risk.

sect2.title: HYMENOLEPIS NANA
sect2.para: H. nana is the smallest of the intestinal tapeworms of humans and the most common tapeworm infection throughout the world. It can cause autoinfection, be transmitted from person to person, or have a zoonotic cycle involving rodents (4, 27, 28). In the autoinfection cycle, eggs hatch in the host’s intestine, releasing oncospheres that invade the mucosa to develop into the larval stage called a cysticercoid within the villi.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: H. nana is included in the phylum Platyhelminthes, subphylum Neodermata, class Cestoidea, subclass Eucestoda, order Cyclophyllidea, family Hymenolepididae, and genus Hymenolepis.

sect2.title: Adult Tapeworm
sect2.para: The adult parasite measures 2 to 4 cm and lives between 4 and 6 weeks. The scolex has four suckers and one crown of hooks.

sect2.title: Eggs
sect2.para: The eggs are 30 to 50 μm in diameter and thin shelled, and contain a six-hooked oncosphere in the center. Four to 8 polar filaments are usually apparent in the wide space between the outer membrane and the membrane of the oncosphere (Fig. 1). These filaments are not present in H. diminuta eggs.

sect2.title: Larvae
sect2.para: The cysticercoid larvae have an invaginated scolex but no fluid-filled bladder. They lodge in the intestinal mucosa and emerge in the intestinal lumen as young tapeworms after a few days.

sect1.title: Epidemiology, Transmission, and Prevention
sect1.para: In its zoonotic cycle,H. nana is a parasite of mice, and beetles act as intermediate hosts. Among humans, the infection is transmitted by ingestion of infective eggs, which release the oncosphere, a parasite stage with the capacity to invade the intestinal mucosa. Within the intestinal villi, the oncosphere turns into a solid-bodied larva called a cysticercoid. Subsequently, the larva migrates back into the intestinal lumen and turns into an adult tapeworm in 2 to 3 weeks. In beetles that ingest eggs of H. nana, the cysticercoids develop in the body cavity and have thick protective walls around them. Although humans may acquire the infection by accidental ingestion of infected beetles often found in dry cereals, direct infection is far more common and is the primary reason why H. nana usually occurs in institutional and familial settings in which hygiene is substandard. A characteristic of human H. nana infection is the potential for autoinfection within the intestinal lumen, which may result in large worm burdens and long-standing infections.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance (Description of Clinical Presentation)
sect1.para: Most infections cause no symptoms. However, hymenolepiasis can be associated with abdominal pain, diarrhea, headaches, or irritability in infections with a higher number of parasites (29, 30). Children may be symptomatic with egg counts as low as 500 eggs/g of stool (31). Invasion of lymph nodes and lungs by abnormal, proliferating, genetically altered tapeworm cells, as in cancer metastasis, has been demonstrated in an HIV-infected individual (32).

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: See instructions in “Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens” forDiphyllobothrium.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Diagnosis of the infection relies on finding eggs by stool microscopy. Flotation and sedimentation techniques increase the sensitivity of microscopy, especially among children with light infections. Proglottids (Fig. 1) are rarely found in stool specimens, because they disintegrate after breaking off from the main strobila. However, parasites may occasionally be identified during colonoscopy. Neither culture, antigen detection, nor nucleic acid detection techniques are relevant for the detection and identification of H. nana.

sect2.title: Serologic Tests
sect2.para: Antibody detection by ELISA has been used in research but is not available for clinical use (33).

sect1.title: Treatment
sect1.para: Both praziquantel and niclosamide are effective drugs. A second dose of praziquantel after 10 to 15 days may decrease the likelihood of relapse. Niclosamide needs to be administered for 7 days because it is not absorbed and thus does not affect the cysticercoid larvae in the intestinal mucosa. Nitazoxanide has been reported as an alternative treatment for hymenolepiasis (34). Treatment of household members may prevent reinfection in children.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Eggs are characteristic and should be reported asH. nana eggs.

sect2.title: LARVAL CESTODES INFECTING THE HUMAN HOST
sect2.para: The larval stages ofT. solium, E. granulosus, E. multilocularis, and, less frequently, Echinococcus oligarthrus, Echinococcus vogeli, sparganosis (Spirometra mansoni, Spirometra ranarum, Spirometra mansonoides, Spirometra erinacei, and Sparganum proliferum), Taenia multiceps, Taenia brauni, Taenia glomeratus, and T. crassiceps can invade the human tissues. These are briefly described below.

sect1.title: T. solium Cysticercosis
sect1.para: Humans are the definitive host and pigs are the usual intermediate host ofT. solium. Pigs develop the larval stage or cysticercus in tissue. Porcine cysticercosis is a serious economic problem for farmers in developing countries. However, the most serious consequences of the infection are associated with human cysticercosis (20). Larval vesicles located in the human central nervous system (Fig. 2) cause seizures or other neurological symptoms. Indeed, neurocysticercosis is associated with a significant proportion of seizure cases in areas of endemicity (35, 36). The clinical manifestations of neurocysticercosis are related to the number, size, and location of the cysticerci and to the severity of the host’s immune response to the parasites. Symptoms and signs are varied and nonspecific. Parasites in the brain parenchyma usually cause seizures and headache, whereas those located in the cerebral ventricles or in the subarachnoid space (“racemose” cysticercosis) cause intracranial hypertension and hydrocephalus. The diagnosis is made using brain imaging, either computed tomography (CT) scans or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), but these methods have different applications. CT has a lower cost (quite important for poor areas where the disease is endemic), is more widely available, and has better sensitivity for the detection of calcified parasites. Conversely, MRI has better sensitivity for small lesions, viable cysts, and subarachnoid and intraventricular parasites. Serology, when available, can aid in the diagnosis. The serologic assay of choice is an immunoblot using seven cysticercal antigens, with a 98% sensitivity and 100% specificity in patients with more than one lesion. In cases with a single lesion, the sensitivity decreases to approximately 70% (25, 26). Antigen detection assays are available through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and may be useful for treatment response evaluation, especially among patients with subarachnoid disease (26, 37). Treatment of neurocysticercosis uses antiparasitic agents (albendazole or praziquantel) for viable parasites, usually given with steroids to ameliorate the inflammation produced by the death of the cyst. The use of albendazole-praziquantel combinations increases treatment efficacy in individuals with multiple brain cysts (38, 39). Surgery is limited to excision of single or large cysts, extraction of intraventricular cysts, or implantation of ventricle-peritoneal shunts.

sect1.title: Cystic Hydatid Disease (E. granulosus)
sect1.para: The life cycle ofE. granulosus includes dogs as the definitive host and herbivores (mainly sheep) as the intermediate host. Herbivores become infected with the larval stage, called hydatids, by ingesting eggs dispersed in the feces of tapeworm-infected dogs. Human cystic echinococcosis is an important cause of morbidity, requiring costly surgical and prolonged medical treatment. This cestodiasis is endemic to most of the Old World, particularly Greece, Cyprus, Bulgaria, Lebanon, Turkey, South America, and Africa. Sporadic autochthonous transmission is currently recognized in Alaska and other states in the United States (40). The affected organs are most commonly the liver and lungs. Although uncommon, the heart, brain, bones, kidneys, and spleen may be affected. The diagnosis is made using ultrasound in solid organs and chest X-ray films in lung infections. CT scan of the abdomen or thorax may help characterize the cysts and potential complications (Fig. 2). Antibody detection by serology may aid in the diagnosis, with an overall sensitivity between 80 to 85%, but with variations depending on cyst location and integrity. Serology is more sensitive for hepatic than for pulmonary cysts and for complicated cysts than for uncomplicated ones. Treatment uses antiparasitic agents (albendazole or albendazole plus praziquantel) for small cysts or before surgery; PAIR (puncture, injection, aspiration, and reinjection), which is an ultrasound- or CT-guided aspiration and sterilization of the cyst cavity; or either laparoscopic or open surgery (41, 42). Spillage of cyst contents could lead to acute anaphylactic reactions or dissemination of infection in the surrounding tissues. Cystic lesions may resolve without therapy in some patients (43).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Larval cestodes infecting the human host. (Top left) T. solium cysticerci in the human brain (neurocysticercosis), shown in a noncontrasted CT scan of the brain. (Top right) E. granulosus hydatid in the human liver (hydatid disease) as seen on liver ultrasound (kind contribution of Enrico Brunetti, Università di Pavia, Pavia, Italy). (Bottom left) Echinococcus multilocularis alveolar hydatid disease in human liver (courtesy of K. Buttenschoen and P. Kern, University Hospital Ulm, Ulm, Germany). (Bottom right) T. multiceps coenurus showing multiple scolices in the cystic wall.

sect1.title: Alveolar Hydatid Disease (E. multilocularis)
sect1.para: The adult stage ofE. multilocularis lives in the small intestine of the definitive host, commonly wild predators in the Northern Hemisphere, occurring in parts of Europe, Asia, Japan, and North America, including Alaska (44, 45). The larval stages infect microtine rodents that usually serve as the common intermediate host. Human infections (causing alveolar hydatid disease) occur by accidental ingestion of the oncosphere by contamination with the feces of the definitive host. The manifestation of alveolar hydatid disease resembles a slowly developing “malignant tumor” of the liver, with subsequent invasion of the blood vessels and bile ducts and metastatic dissemination. The lesions vary in size and can produce minor foci up to large infiltrating structures in the host’s tissue. Thus, alveolar hydatid disease differs greatly in its pathology and clinical course from cystic hydatid disease. This disease often affects people aged over 50 years and is characterized by a chronic course lasting for months or years. Clinical manifestations relate to the extent of tumor-like lesions of the cyst. Besides physical examination, diagnosis usually is based on imaging techniques, including ultrasound, CT, and MRI, supported by serology. Treatment is mainly surgical. Chemotherapy with benzimidazole agents is restricted to residual, postsurgical, or inoperable lesions (46).

sect1.title: Sparganosis (S. mansoni, S. ranarum, S. mansonoides, S. erinacei, and S. proliferum)
sect1.para: Sparganosis is mainly found in Southeast Asian countries, but reports from Eastern Europe, China, and South America are emerging (47–49). The metacestode larvae of Spirometra species can invade the human tissues either by ingestion of contaminated crustaceans in drinking water, by ingestion of infected meat (frog or snake), or by direct contact via a poultice. The most commonly affected sites are subcutaneous tissues and the eye. The diagnosis rests on the pathological demonstration of the larvae after excision by biopsy (47).

sect1.title: Coenurosis (T. multiceps, T. serialis, T. brauni, T. glomeratus)
sect1.para: T. multiceps and T. serialis have canids as definitive hosts and sheep as their normal intermediate host, harboring the larva, or coenurus. The coenurus is a vesicle with a fine membrane, containing a transparent fluid in which multiple (500 to 700) scolices can be seen. Infected sheep rotate in circles continuously, become dizzy, lose their balance and fall (screw disease). These parasites infrequently cause coenuriasis in humans. Human infections have largely been confined to the African continent, but a few cases have been described from France, England, and North and South America. The space-occupying coenurus usually invades the brain, producing lethal lesions. Diagnosis is based on pathological demonstration of the typical larval membrane and multiple scolices (50, 51).

sect1.title: Cysticercosis (T. crassiceps)
sect1.para: T. crassiceps is a common tapeworm of the red fox. Larval forms are generally found in subcutaneous tissues and body cavities of rodents. Human cases are quite rare, mostly in immunocompromised patients (subcutaneous, muscular, or ocular infections) (52, 53).
